messageBody:
Assert: verb. "To state or declare positively and often forcefully or aggressively."  (m-w.com)
 
When you call assert() or one of its siblings, you are saying, "I know this fact to be true, so please abort this operation right away if somehow it isn't!"
 
Asserts can be very useful in production code, but there are a number of considerations to... consider... which would be off-topic right now.  In the context of JUnit, though, they're the meat and potatoes of nearly any test case you write.  They're how JUnit knows whether your test passed or failed--if any assert fails, the test fails, and if no assert fails (and no exception is thrown), the test passes.
 
By the way, all the different varieties of assert() are fundamentally equivalent, but each is tailored to provide a more descriptive failure message for its particular usage.  For example,
 
    assertEquals("Value of b", a, b);
 
is functionally identical to
 
    assert(a.equals(b));
 
But where the former gives an error message like:
 
    Value of b expected: <1> but was:<2>
 
The latter gives just:
 
    junit.framework.AssertionFailedError
 
Quite a difference!
Kevin
